column6: Instruction on contemporary and classic theories and issues in classroom assessment. Students learn about the purposes and strengths of informal and formal, traditional and alternative approaches to classroom assessment. Students examine both selected response assessments and constructed response assessments, develop assessment frameworks, identify alternative models of assessments, evaluate best practices in classroom assessment, and discuss respective advantages and disadvantages of multiple kinds of assessments. Perquisite: none.

(Repeatable once for a maximum of 6 credit hours) Offered on request of school system. Enrollment limited to teachers, administrators or supervisors who are employed in sponsoring system and who are accepted to the university.

Instruction on contemporary and classic theories on and issues in classroom assessment. Students will learn about the purposes and strengths of informal and formal, traditional and alternative approaches to classroom assessment. Students will examine both selected response assessments and constructed response assessments, develop assessment frameworks, identify alternative models of assessments, evaluate best practices in classroom assessment, and discuss respective advantages and disadvantages of multiple kinds of assessments. Perquisite: graduate standing.
Thesis student must register for total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.
Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree Requirements are met.

Introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics used in educational services research: univariate and bivariate techniques (correlations and simple regression); hypothesis testing; non-parametric techniques. Ordinarily taken in graduate course sequence.

Introduction to purposes and practice of qualitative and quantitative research related to educational services. Emphasis on elements of doing research and using products of research to support and enhance practice. Authentic examples used as illustration.

Students develop an understanding of ideas and procedures related to classical test theory sufficient for test development and meaningful interpretation of results from standardized tests and other assessments.

Objectives are to enable students to select and use multivariate methods appropriately, to develop knowledge/skills necessary to conduct multivariate analyses using various statistical packages (SPSS, SAS) and to develop knowledge and skills necessary for interpreting results of multivariate analysis.

column4: Graduate standing; EVAL 65510; and EVAL 78716 or 85515.
column6: This course develops the ability of students to conceptualize and apply the logic and techniques of factor analysis. The focus is on both exploratory and confirmatory procedures.

(Repeatable for credit)Variable topic seminar for advance study of specialized topics and areas in evaluation and measurement; emphasis on theory and research findings as related to educational practice.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM AND INTERNSHIP IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Supervised program in field setting involving application of theories, principles and methodology in evaluation and measurement. Planned with and supervised by graduate faculty member.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Specific topic course offering in response to emerging student or program needs in evaluation and measurement.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Specific topic course offering in response to emerging student or program needs in evaluation and measurement.
(Repeatable for credit)Students pursue an individual research project on a specific topic in evaluation and measurement with approval and under direction of instructor.
Study of principles and techniques of evaluation and measurement, and utilization of evidence to improve teaching, learning and implementation programs.

column2: VARIABLE TOPIC WORKSHOP IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Offered on request of school system. Enrollment limited to teachers, administrators or supervisors who are employed in sponsoring system and who are accepted to the university.

Introduction to descriptive and inferential statistics used in educational services research: univariate and bivariate techniques (correlations and simple regression); hypothesis testing; non-parametric techniques. Ordinarily taken in graduate course sequence.

Instruction on contemporary and classic theories and issues in classroom assessment. Students will learn about the purposes and strengths of informal and formal, traditional and alternative approaches to classroom assessment. Students will examine both selected response assessments and constructed response assessments, develop assessment frameworks, identify alternative models of assessments, evaluate best practices in classroom assessment, and discuss respective advantages and disadvantages of multiple kinds of assessments.

Students develop an understanding of ideas and procedures related to classical test theory sufficient for test development and meaningful interpretation of results from standardized tests and other assessments.

column2: MODERN TEST THEORY: ITEM RESPONSE THEORY
column6: The primary objective of the course is to provide students with knowledge and skills necessary to use item response theory methods and to organize, manipulate, analyze and interpret data from IRT applications. Some of the popular IRT computer programs are introduced.

column4: doctoral standing; EVAL 75510; and EVAL 78716 or 85515.
column6: Students develop the knowledge and skills necessary to use Generalizability Theory (GT) methods as well as to organize, manipulate analyze and interpret data from GT studies.

column4: doctoral standing; EVAL 75510; and EVAL 78716 or 85515.
column6: Objectives are to enable students to select and use multivariate methods appropriately, to develop knowledge/skills necessary to conduct multivariate analyses using various statistical packages (SPSS, SAS) and to develop knowledge and skills necessary for interpreting results of multivariate analysis.

column4: doctoral standing; EVAL 65510; and EVAL 78716 or 85515.
column6: This course develops the ability of students to conceptualize and apply the logic and techniques of factor analysis. The focus is on both exploratory and confirmatory procedures.
Major types of methods used to investigate relationships between two or more variables are introduced; includes various analysis of variance designs analysis of covariance and multiple correlations.

Advanced univariate and introductory multivariate techniques in education research: including analyses of variance and covariance, multiregression and causal modeling, factor analysis, and canonical correlation.
Advanced doctoral residency seminar for students in all areas of educational foundations. Focus on current and emergent issues research and trends in education in multiple settings.

(Repeatable for credit) Doctoral dissertation for which registration in at least two semesters is required, first of which will be semester in which dissertation work is begun and continuing until the completion of 30 hours.
(Repeatable for credit) Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until all degree Requirements are met.

column2: QUANTITATIVE RESEARCH DESIGNS AND APPLICATION IN EDUCATIONAL SERVICES
column6: Quantitative research design and application in educational services research. Spiral presentation of methodological principles within a variety of theoretical frameworks and procedures. Strong focus on computer aided applications to practical problems.

column2: QUALITATIVE RESEARCH DESIGNS AND APPLICATION IN EDUCATIONAL SERVICES
column6: Introduction to theory and practice of qualitative research methods and field studies in educational services. Examination of a variety of strategies including observation, document analysis and interviewing. Ordinarily taken early in doctoral course sequence.

column2: ADVANCED QUANTITATIVE RESEARCH IN EDUCATIONAL SERVICES
column6: Advanced quantitative research design and application in educational services. Statistical packages of instructional strategies with methodological principles focus, theoretical models and practical application of experimental and multivariate research design.

column2: ADVANCED QUALITATIVE RESEARCH IN EDUCATIONAL SERVICES
column6: Utilizes qualitative data in educational services. Applications in qualitative methodology (video techniques) and protocol analysis are applied and evaluated. Generate findings; develop applications to theory; reliability and validity considerations.

(Repeatable for credit) Variable topic seminar for advance study of specialized topics and areas in evaluation and measurement; emphasis on theory and research findings as related to educational practice.

column2: ADVANCED PRACTICUM AND INTERNSHIP IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Supervised program in field setting involving application of theories, principles and methodology in evaluation and measurement. Planned with and supervised by graduate faculty member.
(Repeatable for credit)Specific topic course offering in response to emerging student or program needs in evaluation and measurement.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN EVALUATION AND MEASUREMENT
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Specific topic course offering in response to emerging student or program needs in evaluation and measurement.
(Repeatable for credit) Students pursue an individual research project on a specific topic in evaluation and measurement of education with approval and under direction of instructor.
